{{Infobox video game | title = Harvester | image = Harvester cover.jpg | developer = [[DigiFX Interactive]] | publisher = {{vgrelease|NA|Merit Studios|EU|[[Virgin Interactive]]}} | director = | producer = [[Lee Jacobson]] | designer = Gilbert P. Austin | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = | platforms = [[MS-DOS]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Linux]] | released = {{vgrelease|NA|August 31, 1996|EU|1996}} | genre = [[Interactive movie]], [[Point-and-click adventure game|point-and-click adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] }}
'''''Harvester''''' is a 1996 [[point-and-click adventure game]] written and directed by Gilbert P. Austin, known for its violent content, cult following, and examination of the relationship between fictional violence and actual violence.<ref>{{cite web|last=Elston|first=Brett|title=The bloodiest games you've never played|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/the-bloodiest-games-youve-never-played/?page=3|publisher=Games Radar|accessdate=27 January 2014}}</ref>
== Storyline == The game stars Steve, who awakes with a case of [[amnesia]] in a strange town in 1953 called Harvest. No one there believes he is genuinely amnesiac. All of the town inhabitants are extremely eccentric and many appear to be more a satire or stereotype than real people. They all continuously stress to Steve that he should join the Lodge, which is a large building located at the center of town that serves as the headquarters of the Order of the [[harvest moon|Harvest Moon]]. Steve visits the [[Sergeant at Arms]] at the Lodge, who tells him that all of his questions will be answered inside the building. To enter, he must first join the Order of the Harvest Moon. But in order to join, he must perform a series of tasks that range from simple vandalism to arson for his initiation.
While snooping around town, performing these tasks and learning more about Harvest, Steve visits the Pottsdam residence. Here he meets the overweight and perverted Mr. Pottsdam, who tells Steve that he is to marry his daughter, Stephanie, in a few weeks. Steve meets his alleged wife-to-be upstairs. She explains that she has amnesia as well, and, like Steve, notices that something doesn't seem right about the town. Over a series of days Steve successfully performs all of the required tasks. When he visits Stephanie in her room, he finds nothing but a mutilated skull and spinal cord. He takes it to the Sergeant of Arms and asks him if this is really the remains of Stephanie, to which the Sergeant explains that, inside the Lodge, he will learn the truth, and grants Steve access.
Inside the Lodge Steve visits three floors consisting of mayhem and murder. He must solve various puzzles along the way as well as visit different rooms, referred to as “temples” by their occupants, where he must take on several moral decisions. Eventually he makes it to the Inner Sanctum, where he talks to Principal Herrill of Harvest's Gein Memorial School, who explains that he is second in command of the Harvest Order and is to be addressed as Vice Muck Herrill. The head of the Harvest Order, the Grand Muckity Muck, shares a few short words with Steve, and then attacks him. Steve kills the Grand Muckity Muck and meets the Sergeant at Arms one last time.
He reveals Stephanie to him, who is alive but hooked up to a special torture device, which gave her pain whenever Steve climbed a rope in the Lodge. He releases her from the device and explains to Steve that everything in Harvest is created by a [[virtual reality]] simulator, which he and Stephanie are hooked up to. The Sergeant at Arms explains that this simulation was created in hopes of successfully turning Steve into a [[serial killer]] in [[real life]]. He then gives Steve an ultimatum: Marry and live out the rest of his life with Stephanie in the virtual reality that is Harvest or kill Stephanie. She will die in real life but Steve will be released and free to live in the real world as a serial killer.
If the player chooses to kill Stephanie, Steve beats Stephanie to death and then removes her skull and spinal cord. After the murder is complete, Steve awakens within the virtual reality simulator. Steve, hitchhiking, brutally murders the driver. Steve returns home, where he plays ''Harvester'' with his computer. His mother disapproves the game and criticizes violence in video games by saying that people who watch violence commit violence. Steve ridicules his mother's assertions and laughs at her comparison of violent media to "[[Wile E. Coyote and The Road Runner|Road Runner cartoons]]."
If the player chooses to spare Stephanie's life, the Sergeant at Arms expresses disappointment. Steve says that he'd rather die than become a serial killer, to which the Sergeant at Arms responds that he should enjoy his life "such as it is". Steve marries Stephanie in a ceremony officiated by the Sergeant at Arms and the two have a child together. Their graves are then shown, followed by the death of their bodies in real life as their virtual lives only lasted a few minutes.
== Cast == * Kurt Kistler as Steve Mason ** Ryan Wickerham as the voice of Steve * Lisa Cangelosi as Stephanie * Kevin Obregon as Sergeant at Arms / Technician #1 ** Ryan Wickerham as the voice of Sergeant at Arms * Mary Allen as Mom / Mrs. Pottsdam / Generic PTA Moms * Gilbert P. Austin as Mr. Moynahan * Nelson Knight as Sheriff Dwayne * Bob Cawley as Mr. Johnson * Graham Teschke as Col. Buster Monroe * Tracy Odell as Dark Exotic Woman (as Tracy Napodano) * Mike Napodano as Cue Card Man / Technician #2 * Michael Napodano Jr. as Baby Sister * Tim Higgins as Chessmaster * [[Rheagan Wallace]] as Karin * Roxanne Lovseth as Edna Fitzpatrick * Travis Miller as Mr. Pottsdam * Tom Lima as Kewpie * Christopher Ammons as Jimmy James * Charles Beecham as Postmaster Boyle * Jack Irons as Grand Poobah
== Gameplay== The game utilizes a [[point and click]] interface. Players must visit various locations within the game's fictional town of Harvest via an overhead map. By speaking to various townspeople and clicking on special "hotspots", players can learn information and collect items that progress the game's story and play. ''Harvester'' also features a fighting system where players can attack other characters by selecting a weapon and then clicking on the target. Both the target and the player's character have a limited amount of health available, allowing for either the player or the target to die. Players can choose to progress through the game by solving puzzles or by killing one of the non-playable characters.
== Development and controversy == ''Harvester'' was developed by FutureVision (renamed DigiFX by the time of the game's release). Writer/director Gilbert P. Austin recounted:{{quote|My feeling was that FutureVision, being a small company, would need something “high concept” to compete with the industry giants of the time, and I argued that Harvester was exactly that idea. It was really the only idea that I pitched. I remember that it came to me in a flash. That’s how I get a lot of my ideas, in creative rushes where I can barely write fast enough to get it all down. ... The concept of Harvester, the idea that at the end of the game I wanted the player to mull over whether he had internalized the over-the-top violence and surreal imagery of the game in the same manner that Steve had, and the primary ending…all this was in the initial concept that I jotted down in one of those small reporter spiral notepads in about 30 minutes. That’s what I pitched to FutureVision, and they bought it.<ref name=AM>{{cite web|url=http://gogcom.tumblr.com/post/92424446858/harvester-gilbert-austin-interview|title=Inside Harvester - A Fan Interview with Gilbert P. Austin|last=Malin|first=Aarno|publisher=GOG.com|accessdate=21 July 2014}}</ref>}}
''Harvester'' was first announced to the public at the [[Consumer Electronics Show]] (CES) in January 1994 in Las Vegas.<ref name=AM/> The video footage was all filmed in the back warehouse of publisher Merit Software.<ref name=AM/> Though he was only contracted as the game's writer, Austin voluntarily directed the filming to ensure it stayed true to his vision for the game.<ref name=AM/> Austin finished the creative work in autumn 1994 and moved on to the other projects, leaving producer Lee Jacobson in sole charge of the remaining development.<ref name=AM/> The game was set to be released the same year but the programming took two years to finish, and it became a commercial failure.<ref name=AM/>
In a December 1996 press conference, [[David Walsh (psychologist)|Dr. David Walsh]] released a list of games that he considered to be excessively violent. Jacobson publicly demanded that ''Harvester'', which was not included in Dr. Walsh's list, be added to it.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=What Is Senator Lieberman's Problem with Videogames? |magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=28|publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=April 1997|page=11}}</ref> Gaming journalist Christian Svensson described Jacobson's actions as "shameless", and did not refer to Jacobson, DigiFX, or ''Harvester'' by name so as not to provide positive reinforcement for such publicity seeking.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Svensson |first=Christian |title=Lieberman Back in Action |magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=27|publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=March 1997|page=28}}</ref>
The scene in which children cannibalize their mother was censored in Europe.<ref name=AM/> In Germany, the game was banned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.weirdretro.org.uk/captains-blog/retro-gaming-harvester-1996|title=Retro Gaming: Harvester (1996)|website=Weird Retro|access-date=2016-10-28}}</ref>
The game was designed by DigiFX Interactive and published by Merit Studios in 1996.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=qDDmUujPNezgsATnyYHYBA&id=6eEzAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22Harvester%22+%22+DigiFX+Interactive%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Harvester%22+|title=Computer Gaming World, Volumes 150-153|publisher=Golden Empire Publications|year=1997}}</ref> On March 6, 2014, Lee Jacobson [[Reissue|re-release]]d it in [[GOG.com]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gog.com/news/release_harvester|title=Release: Harvester|author=[[GOG.com]]|date=2014-03-06|publisher=[[CD Projekt]]}}</ref> for PC and Mac. On April 4, 2014, [[Night Dive Studios]] re-released it in [[Steam (software)|Steam]] for PC and [[Linux]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://store.steampowered.com/news/12875/|title=Now Available on Steam - Harvester|author=[[Valve Corporation]]|date=2014-04-04|publisher=[[Steam (software)|Steam]]}}</ref>
== Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = 53/100<ref name="MC">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/harvester |title=Harvester for PC Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=April 27, 2014}}</ref> | AdvGamers = {{Rating|2.5|5}}<ref>{{cite web |last=Indovina |first=Kurt |date=October 30, 2015 |url=https://adventuregamers.com/articles/view/26984 |title=Harvester Review |publisher=[[Adventure Gamers]] |accessdate=October 30, 2015}}</ref> | Allgame = {{rating|2|5}}<ref name=AG/> | GSpot = 6.8/10<ref name="GSpot">{{cite web |last=Hudak |first=Chris |date=August 29, 1996 |url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/harvester-review/1900-2537444/ |title=Harvester Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=April 27, 2014}}</ref> | PCGUS = 82/100<ref name="PCGUS">{{cite web |last=Gamer |first=PC |date=April 27, 2014 |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/harvester-review-december-1996-us-edition/ |title=Harvester review - December 1996, US edition |publisher=[[PC Gamer]] |accessdate=April 27, 2014}}</ref> }}
''Harvester'' received "mixed or average" reviews, according to [[review aggregator]] [[Metacritic]].<ref name="MC"/> ''[[PC Gamer]]'' gave ''Harvester'' a positive review upon its initial release,<ref name="PCGUS"/> but panned it in a 2011 review where they called it the "goriest, most confusing, and above all ''stupidest'' horror game ever."<ref>{{cite web |last=Cobbett |first=Richard |date=May 14, 2011 |url=http://www.pcgamer.com/saturday-crapshoot-harvester/ |title=Saturday Crapshoot: Harvester |publisher=[[PC Gamer]] |accessdate=April 27, 2014}}</ref> ''[[Allgame]]'' remarked that the game's delayed release negatively impacted its reception, as the game felt dated when it was finally released. They felt that this was indicative of the game as a whole, as "conversations with characters are frustrating and often make little sense, plus the manner in which the plot develops is disappointing. ... there are things that are never explained, and the final third of the game is dull and pointless."<ref name=AG>{{cite web|first=Matthew|last=House |title=Harvester |url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=5634&tab=overview|publisher=Allgame|accessdate=27 January 2014|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20141117033258/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=5634&tab=overview|archivedate=November 17, 2014}}</ref> ''[[GameSpot]]'''s review was mixed, as they felt that there was "nothing actually revolutionary going on in ''Harvester''" but praised the game's full-motion video segments as "truly disturbing" and commented that it had "tried-and-true adventure mechanics with entertaining twists".<ref name="GSpot"/>
''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the game a B+."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ew.com/article/1996/12/20/harvester/|title=Harvester|work=EW.com|access-date=2018-11-04|language=en}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox video game |title = Ingress |image = Ingress Logo vector.svg |developer = [[Niantic (company)|Niantic]] |publisher = Niantic |engine = {{unbulleted list|[[LibGDX]]|[[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] (''Ingress Prime'')}} |platforms = {{nowrap|[[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[iOS]]}} |released = <!--The launch of the game in its original form.-->{{Collapsible list | title = December 14, 2013 | titlestyle = font-weight:normal;background:transparent;text-align:left;| '''Android'''|December 14, 2013<ref name="13magnus" />| '''iOS'''|July 14, 2014<ref name="iTunes Shop" />| '''''Ingress Prime'''''|November 5, 2018<ref name="Prime"/>}} }}
'''''Ingress''''' is a [[location-based game|location-based]], [[augmented reality|augmented-reality]] [[mobile game]] developed by [[Niantic (company)|Niantic]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Gregory |first=Myk |url=http://www.wheninmanila.com/ingress-game-lifestyle-social-network/ |title=Ingress: A Game, Lifestyle and Social Network in One! |publisher=When In Manila |date=July 22, 2014 |accessdate=August 7, 2014}}</ref> The game was released for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices on December 14, 2013 and for [[iOS]] devices on July 14, 2014.<ref name="13magnus" /><ref name="iTunes Shop">{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/ca/app/ingress/id576505181?mt=8/ |title=iTunes official App shop |date=July 14, 2014 |access-date=July 14, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Russell |first1=Jon |title=Google’s Ingress augmented reality game quietly launches for iOS devices |url=https://thenextweb.com/google/2014/07/14/googles-ingress-augmented-reality-game-quietly-launches-ios-devices/ |website=TNW News |publisher=The Next Web |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |date=July 14, 2014 |quote=Google is inviting iPhone and iPad owners into its augmented reality game Ingress after it finally launched an iOS app.}}</ref> The game has a [[science fiction]] [[back story]] with a continuous open narrative.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nianticproject.com/ |title=What is this 'Niantic Project'? |publisher=NianticLabs@Google |date=November 1, 2012 |access-date=November 20, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://plus.google.com/+NianticProject/posts |title=Niantic Project}}</ref> ''Ingress'' is also considered to be a location-based [[exergame]].
The competition in ''Ingress'' is primarily between the two opposing factions rather than between individual players, and players never interact directly in the game or suffer any kind of damage other than temporarily running out of "XM", the power that fuels all actions except movement and communication. The gameplay consists of capturing "portals" at places of cultural significance, such as [[public art]], landmarks, [[monuments]], etc., and linking them to create virtual triangular "control fields" over geographical areas.
Progress in the game is measured on an individual level primarily by accumulating "Access Points" (or AP), and AP are awarded for a variety of in-game actions: destroying or damaging an enemy portal, capturing, linking, or recharging a portal, creating a control field, and other actions. Players of opposing factions can "battle" indirectly in approximate real time for control of portals, with one faction attacking a portal to destroy its resources and defenses and the other faction restoring them as they are damaged, but there is no personal penalty for "losing" a portal, the destruction of a field the player created, or any other reason. The only scored competition is between the factions.
{{TOC limit|2}}
== Setting == The game makers' [[framing device]] for the game is as follows: Alongside the discovery of the [[Higgs Boson]] by the physicists at [[CERN]] in 2012,<ref>{{cite web |title=Before Pokémon GO There Was Ingress |url=http://pixelkin.org/2016/07/14/before-pokemon-go-there-was-ingress/ |website=Pixelkin |accessdate=July 20, 2016 |date=July 14, 2016}}</ref> it has also been discovered that the Earth has been seeded with "Exotic Matter" (XM). This substance has been associated with the Shapers, a mysterious phenomenon or alien race.<ref>{{Citation |author1=Haahr, Mads |editor1=Koenitz, Hartmut |editor2=Ferri, Gabriele |editor3=Haahr, Mads |editor4=Sezen, Digdem |editor5=Sezen, Tonguc Ibrahim |title=Interactive digital narrative : history, theory and practice |publication-date=2015 |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-138-78239-6 |chapter=Everting the Holodeck: Games and Storytelling in Physical Space |pages=220–221}}</ref>
=== Factions === Within the game, human reactions to this discovery fall into two opposing factions: the Enlightened fight believing their actions will uplift humanity and bring about the next chapter in human evolution, whereas the Resistance believes that it is protecting humanity from Shaper ingression and preserving humanity's freedom.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://ingresshelp.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/207441277-Faction-choice |title=Faction Choice |accessdate=November 7, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180817023323/https://support.ingress.com/hc/en-us/articles/207441277-Faction-choice |archivedate=August 17, 2018}}</ref> These two factions are the opposing "sides" or "teams" in the game: the Resistance is represented in the game by the color blue and the Enlightened by green. Both teams have naturally tended to balance each other out in population.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Andrew McMillen |title=Ingress: The friendliest turf war on Earth |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/ingress-the-friendliest-turf-war-on-earth/ |accessdate=July 21, 2016 |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=February 17, 2015}}</ref> In some areas, the Resistance are colloquially referred to as "[[The Smurfs|Smurfs]]" and lower-level Resistance players as "Smurflings". Similarly, the Enlightened in general are referred to as "Frogs" or "[[Toad]]s", lower-level Enlightened players as "[[Tadpoles]]".
In real life, the factions occasionally ignore the [[back-story]] and co-operate for the sake of real-life gameplay and [[game balance]]: for example, by establishing neutral zones and rules of engagement; for training new players; for socializing; and occasionally for serious real-life purposes such as honoring fallen heroes.<ref>See [[#MIT-truce]].</ref> Niantic Labs supports these activities and often arranges them.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://plus.google.com/communities/103727946232179539813 |title=Greater Boise Ingress community on Google Plus}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Ingress Live Events |url=https://www.ingress.com/events |website=Ingress |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |quote=Mission Days bring together Agents from both factions to explore cities around the world through the lens of Ingress with unique and local adventures on foot. ... Once a month, First Saturdays are a get together of the local Ingress family, new and old, to level up new recruits, make new friends, and strengthen Cross-Faction relations.}}</ref>
== Gameplay == The gameplay of ''Ingress'' has been described as combining elements of [[geocaching]] with [[capture the flag]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Davis |first1=Michael |title=Ingress in Geography: Portals to Academic Success? |journal=Journal of Geography |date=October 5, 2016 |pages=1–9 |doi=10.1080/00221341.2016.1227356}}</ref>
=== Play environment === [[File:Ingress Intel Map full-screen.png|thumb|right|An example of the Intel Map. Virtual portals ([[octagon]]s with spokes), links (lines joining portals), and control fields (colored spaces) overlay a map of real geographical and civic space via [[Google Maps]]; green represents the Enlightened faction, and blue the Resistance.|295x295px]]
A player using the mobile app is presented with a map representing the surrounding area. The map has a black background and is completely unmarked, except for buildings and roads which are outlined in grey but not labeled, and bodies of water (pale blue). These geographical features are supplied by [[OpenStreetMap]] and formerly [[Google Maps]].{{efn-ua|From the ''Sources'' button found within the Ingress app under the "Device" tab.}} Visible on the map are portals, Exotic Matter (XM), links, control fields, and items that players have dropped from their inventory. Distances from the player to in-game locations are displayed only in [[metric system|metric units]]. The app is available in sixteen languages.{{efn-ua|name=langs|Chinese (Simplified), Chinese (Traditional), Czech, Dutch, English (US), French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Norwegian, Polish, Portuguese (Brazilian), Russian, Spanish, and Swedish. There is also an "Automatic" setting within the app.}}
Players must be physically near objects on the map to interact with them. The mobile client represents the player as a small arrowhead in the center of a circle {{convert|40|m|sp=us}} in radius, which represents the perimeter within which direct interaction is possible. A player sees only their own location, not that of any other player. The color of the arrowhead corresponds with the faction of the player (blue for Resistance, green for Enlightened), as will the XM storage. XM can be thought of as "energy" – a high amount of XM is needed to perform actions in the game, and it can be replenished by walking through an area of XM (common near portals). A player can "hack" a nearby portal to acquire in-game items, some of which can also be used to replenish XM.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://support.google.com/ingress/answer/2808247?hl=en |title=Acquire Items via Hacking |website=Ingress Help |publisher=Google |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714104302/https://support.google.com/ingress/answer/2808247?hl=en |archivedate=July 14, 2015 |accessdate=November 7, 2018 }}</ref>
Players are rewarded with Action Points (AP) for actions within the game. Accumulating AP beyond certain thresholds grants higher access levels,<ref name=fevgames-ap>{{cite web |title=Ingress > Ingress Guide > Concepts > Access Points (AP) |url=https://fevgames.net/ingress/ingress-guide/concepts/access-points-ap/ |website=Fev Games |accessdate=May 22, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160502064342/https://fevgames.net/ingress/ingress-guide/concepts/access-points-ap/ |archivedate=May 2, 2016 |date=May 16, 2016 |quote='''Access Points''' (sometimes referred to as '''Action Points''' and commonly called '''AP''') constitute your “score” in Ingress. Various actions will award you AP. Reaching certain AP thresholds is a requirement for leveling up.}}</ref> i.e., access to stronger items and longer portal recharging capabilities. The access levels are numbered 1 through 16, with 16 being the highest.<ref>{{cite web |author=Ingress |url=https://support.google.com/ingress/ |title=Official Ingress Support Page |publisher=Google |accessdate=February 27, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317232234/https://support.google.com/ingress/ |archivedate=March 17, 2015 }} {{failed verification |date=September 2015}}</ref> Because more AP are awarded for taking over enemy portals than for maintaining your own team's, if a player is outnumbered by members of the other team, they will accumulate AP at a faster rate as a way of leveling the playing field.<ref>{{Citation |author1=Haahr, Mads |editor1=Koenitz, Hartmut |editor2=Ferri, Gabriele |editor3=Haahr, Mads |editor4=Sezen, Digdem |editor5=Sezen, Tonguc Ibrahim |title=Interactive digital narrative : history, theory and practice | publication-date=2015 |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-138-78239-6 |chapter=Everting the Holodeck: Games and Storytelling in Physical Space |page=221}}</ref>
In addition to earning AP, certain actions within the game can earn a player a Badge. Badges are typically multi-tiered (ranked Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, and Onyx respectively) and become a requirement for level advancement starting with Level 9. Most badges are statistic-based: for instance, capturing portals, total MUs captured, fields and links created, various offensive actions, and even successfully discovering new portals. Some badges are exclusive and can only be obtained by attending special ''Ingress'' events.
In September 2014, Niantic Labs introduced missions to the game. A mission is a user-created set of places to visit (''[[waypoint]]s'') and interact with in specified ways. Some missions list all the waypoints from the start, while others only reveal them one at a time as the user progresses from one to the next.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hindy |first1=Joe |title=Huge new Ingress Missions feature will forever change how we play Ingress |url=http://www.androidauthority.com/huge-new-ingress-missions-feature-will-forever-change-how-we-play-ingress-529012/ |website=Android Authority |accessdate=September 8, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140927082848/http://www.androidauthority.com/huge-new-ingress-missions-feature-will-forever-change-how-we-play-ingress-529012/ |archivedate=September 27, 2014 |date=September 25, 2014}}</ref> Completing missions reward the player with a virtual medal of the mission that is displayed on their agent profile.
=== Portals === In the game, Earth has a large number of "portals", made visible by the "scanner" (the mobile phone game app). They are colored green, blue, or grey, depending respectively on whether they are currently controlled by the Enlightened, by the Resistance, or are unclaimed. Players acquire portals for their faction by "deploying" at least one "resonator" on them. They can also add "mods" (modifications) to protect the portals or increase their power in various ways. A portal with no resonators is unclaimed, also called a "ghost" portal.
Players acquire game items (resonators, weapons, etc.) by maneuvering themselves, typically by walking, biking, or driving, to within {{convert|40|m}} of a portal and "hacking" it by selecting this option on their scanners. Any player can hack any portal and receive items, subject to limits on frequency: Hacking a portal starts a "cool down period", initially 5 minutes, until that player can hack that portal again; and attempting more than 4 hacks within 4 hours will cause the portal to "burn out" for that player for 4 hours.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ingress FAQ |url=http://www.ingressportal.com/w/wp-content/uploads/2012/12/IngressFAQ.pdf |website=Ingress Portal |accessdate=January 14, 2016 |page=11}}</ref> These periods can be reduced with the "Heat Sink" and "Multi-hack" mods. Hacking a portal controlled by the opposing faction also earns the player 100 additional AP (Access Points), at the risk of being attacked by the portal in the form of losing XM. Players can also earn additional items and AP for glyph hacking a portal, where they are briefly shown several patterns and retrace them within a time limit.<ref>{{cite web |title=Glyph Hacking |url=https://support.ingress.com/hc/en-us/articles/206618698-Glyph-Hacking |website=Ingress Help |accessdate=March 21, 2017}}</ref> The speed, difficulty and rewards of glyph hacking can be further modified with special Commands.<ref>{{cite web |title=Glyph Hack Command Channel is Open |url=http://decodeingress.me/2015/12/22/glyph-hack-command-channel-is-open/ |website=Decode Ingress |accessdate=March 22, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://plus.google.com/+Ingress/posts/a7Nr6iCt1a7 |website=[[Google+]] |publisher=Niantic |accessdate=March 24, 2016 |title=Agents, the Simple and Complex Glyph can now be entered in the command channe...}}</ref>
To claim a portal for a faction, a player equips, or deploys, at least one resonator on it. If a portal is claimed by the enemy, the player must first neutralize it by destroying the opponents' resonators with weapons called XMP ("Exotic Matter Pulse") Bursters, the principal means of attacking a portal. XM itself is neutral, not aligned with either faction, but an XMP Burster fired by a player of one faction will damage any portal of the other faction within range, while having no effect on portals of the player's own faction.
Portals are typically associated with buildings and landmarks of historic or architectural significance— such as [[sculptures]], [[murals]], and other [[public art]], [[libraries]], [[post offices]], [[memorial]]s, [[places of worship]], [[public transit]] [[Transit hub|hubs]], [[parks]] and other [[recreational]] or [[Tourism|tourist]] spaces, or with business locations.<ref>{{cite web |author=Ingress |url=https://ingresshelp.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/207343987-Candidate-Portal-criteria |title=Candidate Portal criteria |work=Ingress Help |publisher=Niantic Labs |accessdate=September 12, 2015}}</ref> Players may submit requests for the creation of new portals if they meet the level requirements.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://support.ingress.com/hc/en-us/articles/207343987-Candidate-Portal-criteria |title=Candidate Portal criteria |accessdate=April 30, 2016}}</ref> It was thought upon launch that this would allow Google to generate data for its location-based services.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Hodson |first1=Hal |title=Why Google’s ''Ingress'' game is a data gold mine |journal=[[New Scientist]] |date=November 28, 2012 |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg21628936-200-why-googles-ingress-game-is-a-data-gold-mine/ |accessdate=July 20, 2016}}</ref> As of July 2016, 15 million portals had been submitted by the Ingress community, and five million of those had been included in the game.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bogle |first1=Ariel |title=How the gurus behind Google Earth created 'Pokémon Go' |url=http://mashable.com/2016/07/10/john-hanke-pokemon-go/#_qYBgw5Sfmq0 |accessdate=July 20, 2016 |work=[[Mashable]] |date=July 11, 2016}}</ref>
==== Operation Portal Recon ==== In November 2016, "Operation Portal Recon" (OPR) was launched in beta in San Francisco, Tohoku and Kyushu. Operation Portal Recon is a service where high-level Ingress players can evaluate Portal candidates for the Portal Network.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/11/17/niantics-invite-only-portal-recon-tool-lets-players-vote-new-real-world-locations-into-ingress/ |title=Niantic’s new invite-only "Portal Recon" tool lets players vote real-world locations into Ingress |first=Greg |last=Kumparak |publisher=TechCrunch}}</ref> OPR exited beta in May 2017 and made available for all Level 16 players.<ref>{{cite website |url=https://plus.google.com/+Ingress/posts/RnpJxPwdAKU |title=Starting today, Operation Portal Recon (OPR) will now be available globally t... |website=Google+ |publisher=Niantic |date=May 10, 2017 |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> The level requirement for OPR has been reduced several times with the most recent change made in July 2017, making OPR available for all Level 12 players or above.<ref>{{cite website |url=https://plus.google.com/+Ingress/posts/hPZFqa7Q4qs |title=Agents, Level 12 or above now have access to Operation Portal Recon via... |website=Google+ |publisher=Niantic |date=July 11, 2017 |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> Portal Submissions returned to Ingress in September 2017, after a two-year hiatus, as a result of Operation Portal Recon.<ref>{{cite website |url=https://plus.google.com/+Ingress/posts/7sz94RLePop |title=From the intrepid explorers who helped discover countless Portals during the... |website=Google+ |publisher=Niantic |date=September 25, 2017 |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> Niantic announced in September 2018 the ability to submit PokéStop nominations through [[Pokémon Go]] with an initial beta test in South Korea and Brazil. The nominations from the PokéStop Nomination Beta are reviewed by Operation Portal Recon users.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nianticlabs.com/blog/poi-submissions/ |title=Your Neighborhood, Your Game Board |website=Niantic Labs Blog |publisher=Niantic Labs |last1=Hanke |first1=John |date=September 12, 2018 |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://pokemongolive.com/en/post/poi-submission-beta/ |title=PokéStop Nomination Beta Comes to Brazil and South Korea! |website=Pokémon Go |publisher=Niantic Labs |date=September 12, 2018 |access-date=September 16, 2018}}</ref>
=== Portal, links, and control fields === Two portals that have all eight resonators deployed and are controlled by the same faction can be linked by a player from that faction who stands within range of one and has a portal key for the other. (Keys are obtained by hacking but, like most such in-game objects, can be dropped. After twelve hours they disappear, unless picked up by another player.) The maximum possible length of a link depends on the level of resonators on a portal (higher level resonators equal longer linking range) and mods (specifically, link amps and SoftBank Ultra Links). However, one cannot create a link that crosses an existing link from either faction. Both portals must have at least three resonators deployed to maintain the link. The opposing faction can destroy the link by attacking one or both portals so that one portal's resonator count falls below three.
Links between portals may range in length from meters to kilometers or hundreds of kilometers, created in operations of considerable logistical complexity.<ref name=Tran /> International links and fields are not uncommon, as ''Ingress'' has attracted an enthusiastic following in cities worldwide<ref name="d" /> amongst both young and old,<ref>{{Citation |editor1=Wassom, Brian |editor2=Bishop, Allison |author=Wassom, Brian D. |title=Augmented reality law, privacy, and ethics : law, society, and emerging AR technologies | publication-date=2015 |publisher=Amsterdam Syngress |chapter=Chapter 6 – Real Property Rights |page=168 |isbn=978-0-12-800524-8}}</ref> to the extent that the gameplay is itself a [[lifestyle (sociology)|lifestyle]] for some, including [[tattoo]]s.<ref name="13magnus">{{cite web |url=https://plus.google.com/u/0/+Ingress/posts/2wvNoTjd9jG |title=We, at Niantic Labs at Google, are really excited to let you know that our bi... |website=Google+ |publisher=Niantic |date=November 4, 2013 |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref>
When three portals are linked in a triangle, they create a control field, claiming the Mind Units (MU) within that field for their faction. Portals within a field cannot originate links, but can be linked to from any portals on the perimeter (that is, any of the three portals defining the triangle). The opposing faction can destroy a control field by destroying one or more of the links that form it.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://support.ingress.com/hc/en-us/articles/206737888-Create-Links-Control-Fields |title=Create Links & Control Fields |website=Ingress Help| access-date=March 22, 2016}}</ref> The "Mind Units" are related to the population that resides within a control field.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Sascha Lobo |title=S.P.O.N. - Die Mensch-Maschine: Google macht die Welt zum Spielfeld |url=http://www.spiegel.de/netzwelt/web/google-ingress-die-ganze-welt-als-spiel-a-902267.html |accessdate=July 22, 2016 |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=May 28, 2013|trans-title=SPON – The Man-Machine: Google makes the world into a playing field |language=German}}</ref> The largest control field formed had points between Germany, Greece and Ukraine, and took four months of planning and 200 players to create.<ref name=Tran>{{cite news |author1=Edmond Tran |title=Pokemon GO Devs Still Exploring Multiplayer, Say Players Will Shape The Game |url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/pokemon-go-devs-still-exploring-multiplayer-say-pl/1100-6441610/ |accessdate=July 21, 2016 |work=[[GameSpot]] |date=July 7, 2016}}</ref>
In an effort to capture as many MUs as possible, additional fields can be created that blanket other fields. This is called layering, and each subsequent field that is created "recaptures" the MUs from the previous field(s), adding to the count. Layering is most often accomplished by utilizing one or two common portals, called anchors, to host inbound and outbound links and using a unique portal(s) each time to create each additional layered field. Periodically, faction members will coordinate large-scale layered fields that span multiple countries.
== Development and release == ''Ingress'' was released in closed beta on November 15, 2012,<ref name="d">{{cite web |last=Gannes |first=Liz |title=Google Launches Ingress, a Worldwide Mobile Alternate Reality Game |url=http://allthingsd.com/20121115/google-launches-ingress-a-worldwide-mobile-alternate-reality-game/ |accessdate=November 15, 2012 |date=November 15, 2012 |publisher=All Things D}}</ref><ref name="Polygon2012">{{cite web |url=http://www.polygon.com/2012/11/15/3652658/google-launches-ingress-a-mobile-alternate-reality-game-set-in-the |date=November 15, 2012 |title=Google launches Ingress, a mobile alternate reality game set in the real world |author=Tracey Lien |work=Polygon}}</ref><ref name="Joystiq2012">{{cite web |url=http://massively.joystiq.com/2012/11/16/introducing-ingress-the-mmo-by-google/ |date=November 16, 2012 |title=Introducing Ingress: The MMO by Google |author=Elisabeth Cardy |work=Massively by Joystiq}}</ref><ref name="IGNAU">{{cite web |url=http://au.ign.com/games/ingress/android-147945 |title=Ingress Preview, The Sphere of Weirdness explained. |work=IGN Australia}}</ref> with an accompanying online [[viral marketing]] campaign. The latter was noticed as early as November 8, and earlier publicity efforts had been noted at events such as [[San Diego]]'s [[San Diego Comic-Con International|Comic-Con]] on July 12, 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/magazine/2012/11/google-niantic-project/ |work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date=November 12, 2012 |accessdate=November 15, 2012 |first=Michael |last=Andersen |title=Google ARG Hints at Niantic Labs Conspiracy}}</ref> Google employees had been testing the game for at least six months.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nianticproject.ingress |title=Ingress: Android-apps on Google Play |publisher=Google Play |accessdate=November 16, 2012}}</ref> At the time of Ingress's release, Niantic had 35 employees.<ref>{{cite news |title=Niantic’s first AR game Ingress is getting a massive overhaul in 2018 |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/12/2/16725884/ingress-prime-update-niantic-pokemon-go |accessdate=April 16, 2018 |work=The Verge}}</ref>
An early interview described Ingress as a "proof of concept" for other AR games built on Google Maps' data.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Nutt |first1=Christian |title=Q&A: Google Glass and the future of geo-location game Ingress |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/203595/QA_Google_Glass_and_the_future_of_geolocation_game_Ingress.php |website=[[Gamasutra]] |accessdate=July 21, 2016 |date=October 31, 2013}}</ref> It was designed to be aimed at a niche market of gamers.<ref name="Recode">{{cite news |last1=Johnson |first1=Eric |title=Full transcript: Niantic CEO John Hanke talks Pokémon Go on Recode Decode |url=http://www.recode.net/2016/10/4/13166612/john-hanke-niantic-pokemon-go-recode-decode-podcast-transcript |accessdate=January 25, 2017 |work=[[Recode]] |date=October 4, 2016}}</ref> Data from ''Ingress'' was used to populate the locations for Pokéstops and gyms within ''[[Pokémon Go]]'', released in July 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mashable.com/2016/07/10/john-hanke-pokemon-go/ |title=The story behind 'Pokémon Go's' impressive mapping |first=Ariel |last=Borge |date=July 11, 2016 |accessdate=July 13, 2016 |work=[[Mashable]]}}</ref> (See also {{Slink| Pokémon Go| Development}}.)
=== ''Ingress Prime'' === In December 2017, Niantic announced a thoroughly revamped version of the game, branded as '''''Ingress Prime''''', would be released in 2018 using a completely rewritten new client and the lessons learned from the massive popularity of ''Pokémon Go''. The new version features a subtly different back story akin to a [[superhero]] origin theme and a more florid graphic design. Technologically the new version uses Apple's [[ARKit]] and Google's [[ARCore]], and the network layer transitioned from [[JSON]] to [[Protobuf]] in keeping with the engineering style of ''Pokémon Go''.<ref name="Ingress Prime">{{Cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/12/2/16725884/ingress-prime-update-niantic-pokemon-go |title=Niantic’s first AR game Ingress is getting a massive overhaul in 2018 3 Ingress Prime features a new look, new story, and new tech |last=Webster |first=Andrew |date=December 2, 2017 |website=The Verge |access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Network layer details.">{{Cite web |url=https://fevgames.net/beginning-ingress-2-0-prime-announced/ |title=The Beginning: Ingress 2.0 (Prime) Announced |last=n/a |first=Fevenis |date=December 3, 2017 |website=Fev Games |access-date=December 3, 2017}}</ref> The update launched on November 5, 2018 as an update to the existing Ingress game.<ref name="Prime">{{cite web |date=November 5, 2018 |accessdate=November 7, 2018 |title=Welcome to Ingress Prime - Niantic |url=https://www.nianticlabs.com/blog/ingress-prime/ |website=Niantic}}</ref> Niantic also retained the older Ingress game as a separate download named ''Scanner [REDACTED]''. The intention of the older Ingress game is to help aid the transition to Prime as feature parity is reached between both games in 2019. The older game will be available until Ingress Prime offers support for Portal submissions and edits.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=November 19, 2018 |title=Scanner [REDACTED] |url=https://support.ingress.com/hc/en-us/articles/360002076527-Scanner-REDACTED- |website=Ingress Help Center}}</ref>
An [[Ingress (TV series)|anime based on the game]] premiered on [[Fuji TV]]'s +Ultra anime programming block on October 18, 2018. [[Netflix]] will stream the series worldwide on November 23, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Crecente |first1=Brian |title=‘Ingress: The Animation’ Coming to Netflix Timed to October ‘Ingress Prime’ Launch (EXCLUSIVE) |url=https://variety.com/2018/gaming/news/ingress-the-animation-netflix-ingress-prime-1202867371/ |accessdate=July 9, 2018 |work=Variety |date=July 7, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |user=NXOnNetflix |number=1058129246206386176 |date=November 1, 2018 |title=I am thankful for this content we are about to receive. |access-date=November 7, 2018}}</ref>

=== Split from Google === On August 12, 2015, Niantic announced that it was being spun off as an independent company:<ref>Email to players, approximately 01:30 on August 12, 2015 (UTC)</ref> As part of this operation, Google was to begin transferring user data to Niantic on September 11. Users would be able to opt out of this process.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.androidcentral.com/niantic-labs-being-spun-google-independent-company |website=Android Central |title=Niantic Labs is being spun off from Google as an independent company |first1=Dan |last1=Thorp-Lancaster |date=August 12, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150814110243/http://www.androidcentral.com/niantic-labs-being-spun-google-independent-company |archivedate=August 14, 2015}}</ref>
== Special events == In addition to the ongoing competition between the factions wherever there are players, there are several kinds of special events held on specific dates.
=== Anomalies === XM Anomalies are events where players from both factions compete in portal-based games in order to win points for their faction.<ref name= live>{{cite web |website=Ingress |title=Ingress Events— XM Anomalies |url=https://www.ingress.com/events |publisher=Niantic Labs |access-date=August 30, 2018 |quote=These events are for Ingress players of ALL levels and last approximately 4-5 hours including 3-4 hours of walking/biking gameplay and a two hour social meetup at the end. Faction specific groups sometimes plan pre-event get togethers and after-parties.}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Hatfield |first1=Tom |title=Ingress: The game that reveals Google's secret war to control London |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/jun/04/ingress-the-game-that-reveals-googles-secret-war-to-control-london |accessdate=July 22, 2016 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=June 4, 2014}}</ref> The format of an XM Anomaly event occurs over the extent of a weekend with Saturday consisting of the main event. A "series" for the XM Anomalies usually spans two different weekends. Anomaly locations may be chosen based on the player activity in a region. Players, upon registering as being part of the event, organize within each faction into squads based on player level, local knowledge, and mode of transport (for example, walking or biking).<ref name=MajorekduVall>{{cite journal |last1=Majorek |first1=Marta |last2=du Vall |first2=Marta |title=Ingress: An Example of a New Dimension in Entertainment |journal=[[Games and Culture]] |date=March 20, 2015 |doi=10.1177/1555412015575833}}</ref> The largest event, in Japan, attracted over 10,000 players.<ref name="Recode" />
Anomaly sites are divided into two categories: Primary and Satellite locations.<ref>{{cite web |title=Games Event Moved Over Zika Virus Fears |url=https://www.kotaku.com.au/2016/02/games-event-moved-over-zika-virus-fears/ |website=Kotaku Australia |accessdate=March 23, 2018 |date=February 5, 2016}}</ref> Niantic Labs employees, as well as characters from the story, often attend events at Primary anomaly locations. More points are awarded to the prevailing faction at Primary sites than at Satellite sites. Players who participate in an anomaly are awarded a unique badge with the emblem of that anomaly. The outcome of XM Anomalies often influences future events in the plot.
== Reception == [[File:2013SpringCentralWashingtonDCIngressPortalHunt.jpg|thumb| A cross-faction portal hunt convenes in [[Washington, D.C.]], by the [[Smithsonian Castle]] on April 14, 2013. |309x309px]]
=== Scholarship and reviews === ''Ingress'' has been the subject of academic study on the relationship between regionalism and globalism,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Chess |first1=Shira |title=Augmented regionalism: Ingress as geomediated gaming narrative |journal=Information, Communication & Society |date=January 30, 2014 |volume=17 |issue=9 |pages=1105–1117 |doi=10.1080/1369118X.2014.881903}}</ref> and its badge system has been used as an example in a case study of [[gamification]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Kelly Blackwell |title=Gamification – a case study {{!}} Game-Based Learning Compendium| journal= thinkspace.csu.edu.au| url= http://thinkspace.csu.edu.au/gblcompendium/part-3-invitation/gamification-a-case-study/ |accessdate=July 20, 2016 }}</ref> Erin Stark argues that the game's system of players nominating portals based on [[street art]] is in effect the players curating a [[sense of place]] and a more flexible cultural heritage.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Erin Stark |editor1=Michele Willson |editor2=Tama Leaver |title=Social, Casual and Mobile Games: The Changing Gaming Landscape |date=2016 |publisher=Bloomsbury USA |pages=149–163 |isbn=978-1-5013-1058-4 |chapter=Playful places: Uncovering hidden heritage with Ingress}}</ref> Spanner Spencer, writing for [[PocketGamer]], noted that there was no casual way of playing ''Ingress'' and that it demanded dedication and teamwork.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Spanner Spencer |title=If you don't like reality, go somewhere else |url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/iPhone/Ingress/review.asp?c=60572 |accessdate=July 21, 2016 |work=[[PocketGamer]] |date=July 17, 2014}}</ref>
''Ingress'' has been read as a [[gift economy]] in which players swap [[datafication]] of their physical location for gameplay.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Nathan Hulsey |author2=Joshua Reeves |title=The Gift that Keeps on Giving: Google, Ingress, and the Gift of Surveillance |journal=Surveillance & Society |year=2014 |volume=12 |issue=3 |pages=389–400 |url=http://ojs.library.queensu.ca/index.php/surveillance-and-society/article/view/gift |accessdate=July 20, 2016 |issn=1477-7487}}</ref>
''Ingress'' is considered to be a location-based [[exergame]].<ref>{{cite book |editor1=Minhua Ma |editor2=Lakhmi C. Jain |editor3=Paul Anderson |title=Virtual, augmented reality and serious games for healthcare 1 |date=2014 |publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg |location=Berlin, Heidelberg |isbn=978-3-642-54816-1 |page=199 |edition=Aufl. 2014}}</ref> Niantic offers a set of guidelines for players that warn against trespass in its Terms of Service and reinforces that the player is responsible for their own conduct while playing the game. Legal expert Brian Wassom regards this as an important factor in AR games reducing the legal risk they bear when directing players to go to a location.<ref>{{Citation |editor1=Wassom, Brian |editor2=Bishop, Allison |author=Wassom, Brian D. |title=Augmented reality law, privacy, and ethics : law, society, and emerging AR technologies | publication-date=2015 |publisher=Amsterdam Syngress |chapter=Chapter 7 – Torts and Personal Injury |pages=185–186 |isbn=978-0-12-800524-8}}</ref>
Kai-Uwe Werbeck argues that the role-playing of the ''Ingress'' storyline challenges and reinforces [[postmodernism]].<ref>{{Citation |editor1=Byers, Andrew |editor2=Crocco, Francesco |title=The role-playing society : essays on the cultural influence of RPGs |publication-date=2016 |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |publisher=McFarland |chapter=Shapers, Portals and Exotic Matter: Living Fiction and Augmented Reality in Google's Ingress |author=Kai-Uwe Werbeck |page=235 |isbn=978-0-7864-9883-3}}</ref>
==== Awards ==== * ''Ingress'' won a "special mention" at the 2013 Android Players' Choice Awards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/collection/promotion_300055d_players_choice_ctp?hl=en |title=Google Play, Players' Choice Awards, Top Apps and Games of 2013}}</ref> * In 2014, Ingress won the 18th Japan Media Arts Festival Grand Prize for Entertainment Division <ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.j-mediaarts.jp/en/festival/2014/entertainment/works/18e_ingress |title=Japan Media Arts Festival Archive 2014}}</ref>
=== Community and cultural impact === According to Alex Dalenberg of [[American City Business Journals]], as of May 2013 there were about 500,000 players globally.<ref name="Dalenberg2013">{{cite web |url=http://upstart.bizjournals.com/news/technology/2013/05/24/ingress-the-game-taking-over-the-world.html?page=all |date=May 24, 2013 |accessdate=May 25, 2013 |title=Ingress, Google's underground game, is being played all around you |author=Alex Dalenberg |work=Upstart Business Journal}}</ref> In an interview in August 2013 with the fan site ''Decode Ingress'', Niantic Labs founder [[John Hanke]] said "There have been over 1M downloads and a large chunk of those are active."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://decodeingress.me/2013/08/19/interview-with-niantics-john-hanke/ |title=Interview with Niantic’s John Hanke |author=Andrea Di Simone |date=August 19, 2013 |accessdate=August 21, 2013}}</ref> In February 2014 there were 2 million players.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Dean Takahashi |title=Google Niantic’s Ingress aims to make gamers thinner and more social in the real world (interview) |url=https://venturebeat.com/2014/02/09/google-niantics-ingress-aims-to-make-gamers-thinner-and-more-social-in-the-real-world-interview/view-all/ |website=[[VentureBeat]] |accessdate=July 22, 2016 |date=February 9, 2014}}</ref> As of 2015, the game had been downloaded over 8 million times.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Louise Beltzung |title=The King Of Augmented Reality Street Fighting |url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_ca/read/the-king-of-augmented-street-fighting-the-worlds-best-ingress-player |accessdate=July 22, 2016 |work=[[Vice.com]] |date=January 8, 2015}}</ref> In 2015, Niantic told [[Tom's Hardware]] that they had 7 million players.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tomsguide.com/us/endgame-proving-grounds-beta,news-20650.html |publisher=Tom's Guide |title=Meet Endgame: Proving Ground – Google's AR Mobile Game |first=Sam |last=Rutherford |date=March 16, 2015}}</ref>
Speaking with CNN, CEO John Hanke said he didn't expect players to start talking to each other and forming clubs.<ref name=cnn-2013>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/08/26/tech/gaming-gadgets/google-niantic-ingress/ |title=At Google, apps to help discover (and conquer) the world around you |date=August 26, 2013 |accessdate=August 26, 2013 |author=Larry Frum |publisher=CNN}}</ref> Players have leased airplanes, helicopters and boats to reach portals in remote areas of Siberia and Alaska.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Tual |first1=Morgane |title=Plongée dans l'univers d'" Ingress ", le jeu de Google aux frontières du réel |trans-title=Dive into the universe of "Ingress", the Google game at the frontiers of reality |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/pixels/article/2015/03/28/plongee-dans-l-univers-d-ingress-le-jeu-de-google-aux-frontieres-du-reel_4601155_4408996.html |accessdate=July 22, 2016 |work=[[Le Monde]] |date=March 28, 2015 |language=French}}</ref>
In 2015, it was announced that a television series based on Ingress had begun development with producer [[Sean Daniel]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://deadline.com/2015/03/ingress-tv-series-google-game-the-expanse-producer-sean-daniel-1201401843/ |work=Deadline Hollywood |date=March 31, 2015 |author=Nellie Andreeva |title=‘Ingress’ TV Series Based On Google Game In Works With ‘The Expanse’ Producer}}</ref>

Ingress augmented reality game, a ceasefire at MIT and a memorial to slain officer Sean Collier |url=http://www.boston.com/business/technology/innoeco/2013/04/in_googles_ingress_augmented_r.html |work=Boston Globe |author=Scott Kirsner |date=April 24, 2013 |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}</ref> On Sunday, July 31, 2016, 49 players from both factions in South Africa (30 Enlightened, 19 Resistance) collaborated to create a work of field art{{efn-ua |"Field art" refers to creating fields in such a way as to form a picture or artistic design.}}<ref>{{cite web |last1=Alexandra Landvogt |first1=Alexandra |title=(Christmas Butterfly) |quote=The well-known Christmas Butterfly has landed and almost covered the city of Heidelberg. |url=https://plus.google.com/+AlexandraLandvogt/posts/7kyTyA4583L |website=RNK Field Art (Rhein-Neckar-Kreis-Ingress-Art) |accessdate=August 14, 2016 |date=December 15, 2013}} '''[[#RNK-Field-Art|*]]'''</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Müller |first1=Florian |title=Frohe Ostern euch allen |trans-title=Happy Easter everyone |language=German |url=https://plus.google.com/+FlorianM%C3%BCllerKeibertz/posts/bbtwFAR3CYv |website=Google+ |accessdate=August 14, 2016 |date=April 20, 2014 |quote=We build this huge #Easterbunny for you, to show what #Chrossfaction can do sometimes.}} '''[[#RNK-Field-Art|*]]'''</ref><ref>{{anchor|RNK-Field-Art}}'''<nowiki>*</nowiki>''' ''RNK Field Art (Rhein-Neckar-Kreis-Ingress-Art)'' is linked on the official Ingress website. {{cite web |title=Ingress Google+ Communities Directory |url=https://www.ingress.com/community/directory |website=Ingress (official website) |accessdate=August 14, 2016}}</ref> of a rhinoceros, covering approx. {{convert|325|km²|sqmi}}, to raise awareness of rhino poaching in Southern Africa.<ref>{{cite web |last1=van der Wal |first1=Kevin |title=Kevin van der Wal (V3T1S): OPERATION: SAVE THE RHINO |url=https://plus.google.com/+KevinvanderWalV3T1S/posts/4gfphKLFCZW |website=Google+ |accessdate=August 13, 2016 |date=August 1, 2016 |quote=“Since 2008 poachers have killed at least 5,940 African rhinos......” (https://www.savetherhino.org) South Africa has by far the largest population of rhinos in the world and is an incredibly important country for rhino conservation. ... Because of these horrendous statistics and a tremendous love for our wildlife, it was decided that we will do an X-faction field art OP to raise awareness of Rhino poaching in South Africa.}}</ref>
=== Criticism and incidents === The basic idea of ''Ingress'' is very similar to that of the older, now-defunct, augmented reality game, ''[[Shadow Cities]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Google Accused Of "Blatantly" Ripping Off Grey Area Games’ Shadow Cities |url=http://indiestatik.com/2012/11/27/google-accused-of-blatantly-ripping-off-grey-area-games-shadow-cities/ |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121129084454/http://indiestatik.com/2012/11/27/google-accused-of-blatantly-ripping-off-grey-area-games-shadow-cities/ |work=Indiestatik | archive-date=November 29, 2012 |author=Chris Priestman |date=November 27, 2012 |accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref> Both have two factions which are fighting for the future of the world with smart phones. Though the games have similar game mechanics and look-and-feel, there are clear differences. In ''Shadow Cities'', players are in the virtual world, which is dynamically mapped around them, and can teleport within the virtual world, whereas in ''Ingress'', the portals are real world locations that players generally have to actually move to in order to play.<ref>{{cite news |title=Inside Ingress, Google’s Augmented Reality Android Game |url=http://www.geekosystem.com/google-ingress-review/ |work=Indiestatik |author-first= Glen | author-last=Tickle |date=January 15, 2013 |accessdate=December 14, 2013}}</ref> ''Shadow Cities'' was shut down on October 7, 2013 due to lack of popularity.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/09/20/shadow-cities-closing-down-october-7/ |title=Shadow Cities closing down October 7 |work=Engadget | author-first=Shawn | author-last= Schuster |date=September 20, 2013 |accessdate=December 13, 2015 |quote=Finnish developer Grey Area has announced that they will be closing down ''Shadow Cities'' on October 7 of this year. The game has already been removed from the iTunes App Store as of today and it will not accept new Mana Potion purchases.}}</ref>
Portals which had been approved within the [[Nazi]] [[concentration camp]]s of [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]] and [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp|Sachsenhausen]] were removed in July 2015; Gabriele Hammermann, director of the memorial site at Dachau, told the [[Deutsche Presse-Agentur]] that Google's original approval of these portals was a humiliation for victims of the Nazi camps and their relatives, and Niantic Labs' founder John Hanke stated that "we apologize that this has happened."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/googles-niantic-labs-sorry-over-death-camps-smartphone-game-n385741 |title=Google's Niantic Labs Sorry Over Death Camps in Smartphone Game |agency=Associated Press |publisher=NBC News}}</ref>
Some players have attracted the attention of [[law enforcement]] while playing the game, and hence commentary on the interaction of augmented reality games with real life.<ref>"[http://readwrite.com/2012/12/11/augmented-reality-game-gets-player-arrested-the-first-of-many Augmented Reality Game Gets Player Arrested the First of Many]", ''Read Write Web'', December 11, 2012.</ref> Because it can take some time for players to successfully "hack" a portal, they can draw the attention of law enforcement. In addition, some players play while driving slowly around an area, which is not recommended by the game developers and attracts the attention of law enforcement.<ref>{{Citation |editor1=Wassom, Brian |editor2=Bishop, Allison |author=Wassom, Brian D. |title=Augmented reality law, privacy, and ethics : law, society, and emerging AR technologies | publication-date=2015 |publisher=Amsterdam Syngress |chapter=Chapter 8 – Criminal Law |pages=209–210 |isbn=978-0-12-800524-8}}</ref> The [[Center for Internet Security]] recommended that law enforcement officers be apprised of the game, and warned that it may be difficult to determine if a malicious actor is using the game as a cover.<ref>{{cite web |title=Google's Ingress Game Will Likely Increase Reports of Suspicious Activity |url=https://msisac.cisecurity.org/daily-tips/google-ingress-game.cfm |website=MS-ISAC Cyber Tips Newsletter |accessdate=July 22, 2016}}</ref> Furthermore, players have used unofficial apps to [[stalking|stalk]] each other.<ref>{{cite news |title=Ingress Players Use Unofficial Tools To Stalk One Another |url=https://kotaku.com/ingress-players-use-unofficial-tools-to-stalk-one-anoth-1820196357/amp |accessdate=November 9, 2017 |work=''kotaku.com''}}</ref>
In 2014, a 16-year-old player in Brazil died after being hit by a bus while playing.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Carlos Alberto Teixeira |title=Jogador de game do Google morre após ser atropelado na Tijuca |url=http://oglobo.globo.com/sociedade/tecnologia/jogador-de-game-do-google-morre-apos-ser-atropelado-na-tijuca-11571559 |accessdate=September 5, 2018 |work=[[O Globo]] |language=Portuguese| trans-title= Google game player dies after being hit in Tijuca |date=February 11, 2014}}</ref> In 2015, an Irish player fell into the sea and drowned while trying to capture [[Poolbeg Lighthouse]] at night.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Louise Roseingrave |title='Life is a living nightmare without him' – Online gamer died on night-time 'mission' at Poolbeg lighthouse |url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/life-is-a-living-nightmare-without-him-online-gamer-died-on-nighttime-mission-at-poolbeg-lighthouse-34709182.html |accessdate=July 20, 2016 |work=[[The Irish Independent]] |date=December 5, 2015}}</ref>

'''Interpretive planning''' is an initial step in the planning and design process for [[informal learning]]-based institutions like [[museum]]s, [[zoo]]s, [[Science museum#Science_center|science center]]s, nature centers, [[botanical garden]]s, heritage sites, parks and other cultural facilities where interpretation is used to communicate messages, stories, information and experiences. It is a decision-making process that blends management needs and resource considerations with visitor needs and desires to determine the most effective way to communicate a message to a targeted audience.<ref>[http://www.definitionsproject.com/definitions/def_full_term.cfm National Association for Interpretation]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
Interpretation at [[informal learning]] institutions builds on [[Freeman Tilden]]’s principles of [[Heritage interpretation|interpretation]], focusing especially on ''relating'' content in a meaningful way to a visitor’s own experience, ''provoking'' emotion, thought or further inquiry into a subject. The communication goals of interpretation at [[Mission statement|mission-based]] institutions are based on achieving previously specified outcomes.<ref>[http://www.heritagedestination.com/interpretive-planning.aspx Heritage Destination Consulting]</ref> Most interpretive plans are based on a [[Thematic interpretation|thematic approach to interpretation]], and therefore, place emphasis on which themes are important to communicate to various audiences.<ref name="Brochu (2003)">{{cite book|last=Brochu|first=Lisa|title=Interpretive Planning: The 5-M Model for Successful Planning Projects|year=2003|publisher=InterpPress|location=Fort Collins, CO|isbn=1-879931-12-5}}</ref> Interpretive planning may also guide how audiences will react to and interact with a particular site or exhibit. <ref>[https://www.historyassociates.com/resources/blog/interpretive-planner-insights/[[History Associates]]]</ref>
An interpretive plan establishes these specific goals for an institution’s market(s) and builds a structured vision of how to achieve them by communicating to an audience through appropriate and meaningful experiences. It combines developing, organizing and analyzing content into relevant and engaging messages, with creating exciting ways for visitors to experience this content.<ref>[http://www.aldrichpears.com [[AldrichPears Associates]]]</ref> An interpretive plan establishes the communication process, through which meanings and relationships of the cultural and natural world, past and present, are revealed to a visitor through experiences with objects, artifacts, landscapes, sites, exhibits and people.<ref>[http://www.interpcan.ca/new/ Interpretation Canada]</ref>
To effectively engage a visitor and achieve these objectives, as well as any other institutional objectives and requirements (financial, operational, environmental, etc.), an interpretive plan is built through addressing the following issues: # Why do you want to interpret something? # Who should be involved in the interpretive process? # What are you interpreting? # Who you are interpreting for? # What messages do you want to communicate? # What are your specific objectives? # What media will you use? # How will your interpretation be implemented? # How will it be evaluated? # How will it be maintained? <ref>[http://www.snh.gov.uk/policy-and-guidance/heritage-interpretation/interpretive-planning/ Scottish Natural Heritage]</ref>
The resulting product provides a vision for the future of [[Heritage interpretation|interpretation]], [[education]], and visitor experience opportunities. It identifies and analyzes interpretation, education, and visitor experience goals and issues and recommends the most effective, efficient, and practical ways to address those goals and issues.<ref>[http://www.nps.gov/hfc/products/ip-lrip.htm [[National Park Service]]]</ref> The plan guides the further design and development of the project, becoming a resource for [[architecture]], [[Exhibit design|exhibit development]] and [[fundraising]].<ref>[http://www.woed.com/services/master.html West Office]</ref>
